subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Private methods reduce duplication within the one class. They do nothing to reduce duplication within the entire system. Extracting them to public methods
messageBody:
Jim Cakalic wrote:

>How so? My experience is that private methods are frequently
>introduced specifically to remove duplication.
>
>

Private methods reduce duplication within the one class. They do nothing
to reduce duplication within the entire system. Extracting them to
public methods on an appropriate class does.

Consider a method to parse a String into a Calendar. This is boiler
plate code. Do it a few times in a class, and you'll end up making a
private method. However, when Jane over there wants to turn a String
into a Calendar in a different class, she doesn't know about the private
method you wrote - because it's _private_.

Private methods are the most common violator of the
Single-Responsibility Principle, in my experience. Wanting to test them
is a symptom, to me, of a violation of the SRP. Exposing private
methods as public, on an appropriate class, helps me to avoid
SRP-violations, and helps promote reuse to reduce duplication.

The other driver I have to make private methods public is explicitly to
reduce duplication. For example, maybe it's you doing the
String-to-Calendar trick in another class. You know where you did it
before, so you extract it out and reuse it. However, this only works
because you're familar with what you did earlier - it didn't work for
Jane because she wasn't.

Robert.
